intro: Cyathocephalum schmidtii, commonly known as the Schmidt's cup-cress, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many species with small, four-petaled flowers. The plant is characterized by its compact growth habit and distinctive, cup-shaped inflorescence that houses numerous tiny flowers. Its leaves are typically narrow and hairy, adapted to reduce water loss in dry environments. Cyathocephalum schmidtii is often found in rocky or sandy soils and is well-suited to survive in harsh, semi-desert conditions.
